race.name: Ned Gravel
race.tagline: Colorado State Championship mountain gravel in the Front Range.

climate.description: Variable mountain conditions with altitude, cool temperatures, and afternoon storms possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colorado Rockies. Significant elevation with high altitude starting at 8000+ feet.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Colorado State Championship. Mountain terrain and altitude are significant but state/regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Ned Gravel is Colorado's State Championship gravel race—mountain terrain in the Front Range with significant climbing and high altitude. Nederland sits at 8,000+ feet, and the course climbs from there. The state championship status and Colorado Rockies setting elevate it above typical regional events, but it's still a state-level field. Near Boulder with moderate access. Well-organized for a state championship.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Colorado State Championship gravel race with high-altitude mountain terrain. Worth it for Colorado cyclists seeking state championship status and mountain challenge. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers, but a legitimate mountain test.

final_verdict.one_liner: Colorado State Championship mountain gravel with high altitude.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Colorado and want state championship status with mountain terrain—yes, it's a solid event. If you're from out of state—there are more prestigious options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Colorado events: Leadville Trail 100, Crusher in the Tushar. For similar state championships: other state championship events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Nederland has limited lodging. Boulder or Denver have more options.
logistics.food: Mountain town with moderate dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: High-altitude mountain gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: High-altitude mountain climbing in Colorado Rockies.

non_negotiables.why: Starting at 8000+ feet requires serious altitude preparation or early arrival.
6000 feet of climbing at altitude requires serious fitness.
Colorado mountain weather is variable with afternoon storms possible.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Colorado State Championship mountain gravel with high altitude.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: State championship in the Front Range Rockies.

logistics.explanation: Staggered start times from 7:00-8:00 AM with parking closing at 7:30 AM sharp creates tight timing windows. Kate's navigation error that led her "off course farther than I'd like to admit" highlights course marking challenges. Race director Gavin Coombs notes learning "something to make the next year even better" after each event, suggesting ongoing logistics refinement.

length.explanation: The 70-mile Tungsten course with 8,300 feet of climbing offers substantial suffering without epic mileage. Hannah finished the 50-mile Gold course "under 5 hours" as her goal, while the Ultra distance features a "strict cutoff time of 12 hours." Aid stations can be "up to 90 minutes apart" requiring riders to carry substantial nutrition between stops.

technicality.explanation: Switzerland Trail features "railroad grade between 2% and 6%" that's "sandy and bumpy but not too technical." However, riders face "gnarly babyhead rocks, sheer cliffs, steep climbs and descents" where "line choice was everything." Rowena Trail requires "designated, optional dismount zones" due to technical difficulty, while road shoes are "STRONGLY discouraged" due to mandatory walking sections.

elevation.explanation: Sugarloaf Road delivers "the steepest pitch of the course (17%!)" while Mammoth Gulch climbs to the highest point at 10,300 feet through Apex Ghost Town. Hannah noted still "learning how to push through hard climbs (Nederland hills are no joke)." The 8,300 feet of total climbing on Tungsten creates sustained vertical punishment at high altitude.

climate.explanation: The 2022 edition featured "unusually hot weather, even at a minimum of 8,200' elevation" with riders advised to "prepare for hot weather but bring a rain jacket in case of afternoon thunderstorms." Hannah struggled with "learning how to stay cool in the summer heat" despite the elevation. The 2025 race morning saw "early morning sun rose and dark clouds loomed over the reservoir."

altitude.explanation: Racing between 8,200-10,300 feet creates immediate oxygen debt with zero acclimatization time during the event. The course reaches its highest point at Mammoth Gulch around 10,300 feet, passing through ghost towns where altitude historically claimed lives. Hannah noted the challenge of high-elevation climbing while multiple elite riders struggled with heat management despite the thin air.

adventure.explanation: The course passes through Deadwood Diggins "where the first gold in the area was discovered in 1859" and Apex Ghost Town at 10,300 feet elevation. Lailah crashed hard enough to crack her helmet "clean through directly at the center" but still plans to return to "conquer the Switzerland Trail; it's personal now!" CR103 provides "guaranteed to be one of your most fun descents ever" through authentic mining country.

prestige.explanation: Five years old with zero pro field mentions or YouTube coverage makes this a regional player, not a destination event. The Tungsten course joined Colorado's Summer of Gravel series in 2023, which adds some credibility. But when your biggest selling point is inclusivity rather than brutality, you're not hunting prestige points.

race_quality.explanation: Multiple elite riders crashed with "many of the fastest riders on the Ultra distance coming in bloody" at the mid-point, indicating challenging but potentially under-marked terrain. Lailah suffered a concussion requiring medical clearance after her Switzerland Trail crash. The race provides solid organization with four distance options, though navigation errors and crash rates suggest room for safety improvements.

experience.explanation: Aimee crashed on Mammoth Gulch descent with a "solid smash to the knee" but continued to third place overall, demonstrating the consequential terrain. Cold Springs Road offers "punchy uphills and fast descents" while the course promises "climbs will challenge you, the descents will make you smile and the views will take your breath away." Post-race features live music, food trucks, and free beer for finishers.

community.explanation: Hannah felt she'd "made my own little space in the gravel community, and there are some pretty rad humans there with me!" The first week of registration is reserved exclusively for women, BIPOC, non-binary athletes, and Para Cyclists. Kate experienced "the kindness and support of the gravel community" including help from strangers on and off course, while one rider stopped mid-Ultra "to have a beer at Tin Shed before continuing."

field_depth.explanation: The 2025 field included 551 riders with documented elite women like Lailah, Kate, Hannah, and Aimee competing seriously. However, the race emphasizes inclusivity over competition with priority registration for underrepresented groups and marketing focused on welcoming beginners. Elite riders treat it as a challenging training event rather than a marquee competitive target.

value.explanation: Four distance options from 10 to 70 miles accommodate different experience levels and budgets. The event generates "expected to top $50,000 in local contributions" for youth sports through the nonprofit Peak to Peak Endurance Foundation. Post-race expo includes "live music, food trucks, beer, and vendors" with every finisher receiving a free beverage, providing solid event value beyond the race itself.

expenses.explanation: Nederland location in Boulder County requires Front Range travel costs but avoids resort-town pricing. Minimum 38mm tubeless tires are "STRONGLY" recommended with cycling shoes featuring walkable cleats due to mandatory dismount sections. Parking closes at 7:30 AM requiring overnight stays for most riders, while riders need lights and self-rescue capability adding to gear requirements.

key_takeaways: A new Bronze course was introduced in 2024
